brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine whether the peripheral balloon dilatation catheter
      (trade name: Iris) is safe an effective in PTA procedure.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness and Safety Study of Peripheral Balloon Dilatation Catheter in Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty(PTA) Procedure
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Multicenter and Single-arm Target Value Clinical Study on the Efficacy and Safety of Peripheral Balloon Dilatation Catheter in PTA Procedure

primary_outcome.description:
successfully pass lesion(s)
successfully dilate lesion(s)( diameter of balloon reach at least 90% of the nominal diameter)
successfully retrieve
The definition of technical success rate of PTA procedure is that, all of the above 3 point are successful
primary_outcome.measure: technical success rate of PTA procedure

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description:
relevant balloon complications occurred during procedure(failure of balloon inflation, rupture of the balloon, failure of balloon deflation, failure of withdrawn, catheter fracture, etc.).
Relevant major vascular complications occurred during procedure (rupture of blood vessels and acute vascular occlusion caused by dilation).
secondary_outcome.time_frame: day 2 to day 10 after procedure or hospital discharge

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
